Five times that are not good for meditat: A mendicant is old, overcome with old age.
A mendicant is sick, overcome by sickness.
There’s a famine, a bad harvest, so it’s hard to get almsfood, and not easy to keep going by collecting alms.
There’s peril from wild savages, and the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.
There’s a schism in the Saṅgha.
Five times that are good for meditation: A mendicant is a youth, young, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
They are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.
There’s plenty of food, a good harvest, so it’s easy to get almsfood, and easy to keep going by collecting alms.
People live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
The Saṅgha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, with one recitation.
